key_points: Governor Andrew Cuomo's office underreported Covid-19 related nursing home deaths in New York in spring 2020.
The underreporting was allegedly to avoid triggering a federal investigation by the Trump administration.
Howard Zucker, the state health commissioner, had mandated nursing homes to admit infectious Covid patients, contributing to the spread.
Cuomo did not lift this mandate until May 10, after substantial deaths had occurred in nursing homes.
New York's official count admitted to about 7,000 nursing home deaths, though estimates suggested around 12,000.
Attorney General Letitia James reported the real death toll to be close to 13,000.
Cuomo has faced criticism for his handling of the pandemic despite initially receiving national acclaim and media adulation.
Cuomo won an Emmy in 2020 for his daily Covid-19 briefings and became a celebrated figure amidst the pandemic.
Melissa DeRosa, Cuomo's top aide, acknowledged the stonewalling was to avoid federal scrutiny.
The Biden Justice Department is not expected to pursue investigations into Cuomo's actions.
